abstract.p: Grace Glueck reviews work on late Indian painter Acharya Vyakul, at Lawrence Markey Gallery (S)

block.p: Working only when the spirit seized him, the Indian painter Acharya Vyakul (1930-2000) used all manner of materials -- plants, cow's urine, clay, coal, flowers and powders -- to produce his small, simple but highly charged watercolors.

Working only when the spirit seized him, the Indian painter Acharya Vyakul (1930-2000) used all manner of materials -- plants, cow's urine, clay, coal, flowers and powders -- to produce his small, simple but highly charged watercolors.

The paintings are in a ''tantra-folk'' style -- often accomplished with his fingers rather than a brush -- that melds mystical Hindu-Buddhist images with popular art, ranging from enchanting primitive monster figures to an explosion of marks like fingerprints that suggests a floral spray.

Sometimes he makes abstract calligraphs, like a bright aqua-blue Y-shape, or a creepy snake curve in green outlined in yellow. A recurrent image is a washy ovoid mass with eyelike circles in its middle. The strongest works are those that evoke human or chimeric bodies, like a gesturing dragon-y figure in muddy brown that has a mischievous look, or a lumpy, disjointed figure of a woman that resembles the Venus of Willendorf.
Although they are modest in size, these works have an infectious energy.
